keyTakeAways: A devastating fire broke out at the logistics section of the main airport in Bangladesh on Saturday, with damages estimated at over $1 billion.
The fire destroyed clothes, raw materials, and essential samples used for securing new buyers, potentially affecting the global garment supply chain.
Bangladesh is the world's second-largest exporter of clothing after China, supplying major retailers like H&M and Walmart, making the incident highly relevant to global fashion markets.
The garment sector contributes around $40 billion annually to Bangladesh’s economy, accounting for over a tenth of its GDP, emphasizing the national and global economic stakes.
The blaze took 27 hours to extinguish and temporarily halted airport operations and flights, disrupting logistics during the pre-Christmas rush.
Around 35 people were injured while working to contain the fire, and the cause remains under investigation.
The damaged cargo village is a key logistics hub storing fabrics, pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and other goods, especially during peak demand periods.
Conspiracy theories have circulated online, suggesting the three fires were pre-planned, drawing on past political misuse of tragedies.
The interim government pledged immediate action if credible evidence of sabotage or arson is found, indicating heightened scrutiny and public concern.
Fires are frequent in Bangladesh due to poor infrastructure and weak safety enforcement, with hundreds of deaths in recent years.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major fire at Bangladesh's main airport logistics section on Saturday caused extensive damage, with estimates of over $1 billion in losses. The fire destroyed critical goods including raw materials and essential samples used to secure new international buyers, disrupting a sector that accounts for over $40 billion annually in exports and more than 10% of the country’s GDP. The incident occurred during the pre-Christmas rush, when the cargo village—a key logistics hub—was operating at peak capacity. The blaze, which took 27 hours to extinguish, temporarily halted airport operations and injured around 35 people. This is Bangladesh’s third major fire in a week, with two prior incidents involving a deadly warehouse fire and a clothing factory fire in Chittagong. Conspiracy theories suggest a possible link between the events, raising concerns about sabotage or arson, particularly given a history of political exploitation of such tragedies. The interim government has promised firm action if credible evidence of foul play is found. Experts attribute the frequency of fires to poor infrastructure and weak safety enforcement, with hundreds of deaths recorded in recent years.
title: Bangladesh airport inferno estimated to cost $1bn in damages
